column3: Would it suffice to log this once at startup instead? It's an immutable string anyway.\n
@sipa well, yes, but they same could be said for other items in the version string, e.g. protocol version - do you want these moving out of the line per node also?\n
@rebroad That sounds reasonable; no need to log it on every established connection.\n

Automatic sanity-testing: PASSED, see http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/p4829_99c9399a436b2af7fb94545f7c48f15760e6c4fe/ for binaries and test log.\nThis test script verifies pulls every time they are updated. It, however, dies sometimes and fails to test properly.  If you are waiting on a test, please check timestamps to verify that the test.log is moving at http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-te
Indeed, one-time information should usually be returned via an RPC call.  No need to log same information repeatedly at all, even at startup.\n

Not sure I understand. This is logged only once in the debug.log now, as @sipa requested. Do we want it logged once, or every time it's used? It was initially every time, (as was PROTOCOL_VERSION), but then I changed it to just once.

There's much info in debug.log that isn't available via RPC, so I'm assuming you're not suggesting we move everything to RPC instead.

The protocol version is already in RPC.  It makes sense to export that alongside.

Logs are awful for parsing.
@jgarzik I'm not interested in using RPC currently. I just want it logged somewhere, hence this pull request.\n

Agree with @jgarzik here. I think what you're trying to do (collect statistics by parsing the log) is misguided. The log is not an interface, RPC is. A better solution would be to have an external tool periodically collect the information through RPC. This is what I'm trying to say in  https://github.com/rebroad/bitcoin/commit/a973b79e78cf4139efd8d778736cb7831ce775b6#commitcomment-7654200 too.\n
@laanwj This pull request is unrelated to my stats collection. This pull request is just to store somewhere what the version string we are sending to clients looks like.\n
Added #4914 which exports this information via much more easily parseable RPC/json.\n
Not 100% sure what you are trying to accomplish with this, but wouldn't it be better to offer this information on RPC (`getnetworkinfo`)? That's easier to query than searching in the log.\n
